The Reflector.text:
Jungian archetype: The Self (wholeness and reflection)
Civic role: The reflective citizen
Values: Insight, Empathy, Context
Shadow: Sees the complexity but hesitates to act.
Gift: Creates understanding where others get stuck in polarization.
Message: Reflection is not passivity. It is a way of taking the world seriously.
After a few years: Society has become deeply thoughtful. Understanding is high – but some decisions are delayed.
Reflective question: When a decision must be made quickly, do you often want to understand all consequences first, even if others already want to move on?
Advice: Choose one insight that feels clear enough and put it into action — adjustments can come later.

The Burner.text:
Jungian archetype: The Shadow (repressed power and change)
Civic role: The change driver
Values: Courage, Change, Authenticity
Shadow: Tears down before something new has been built.
Gift: Dares to say the unspeakable when the system has hardened.
Message: Anger is often care that hasn’t been heard.
After a few years: Society has changed quickly. Much is new — not everything is finished.
Reflective question: When something feels wrong, is your first impulse to speak up immediately rather than wait for consensus?
Advice: Aim your force at a clear next step so the change can hold over time.

The Negotiator.text:
Jungian archetype: The Persona (social adaptation)
Civic role: The social navigator
Values: Consensus, Social trust, Stability
Shadow: Avoids conflict even when it is needed.
Gift: Keeps the conversation alive when it would otherwise break down.
Message: Diplomacy is not lying — it is carrying relationships through difficult rooms.
After a few years: Society is stable and friendly — but some issues remain under the surface.
Reflective question: When a conflict arises, do you often try to calm the situation even if your own view has to step back?
Advice: Say what matters early and calmly — it often creates more safety than silence.

The Archivist.text:
Jungian archetype: The Sage (knowledge and truth)
Civic role: The knowledge citizen
Values: Knowledge, Long-term thinking, Responsibility
Shadow: Is right, but without impact.
Gift: Preserves collective memory when others want to move on.
Message: Truth is not always popular, but it endures.
After a few years: Society knows what should have been done — sometimes only in hindsight.
Reflective question: Do you often want to understand the full background before you propose a solution?
Advice: Share your knowledge in smaller steps — action can happen even before everything is known.

The Caretaker.text:
Jungian archetype: The Caregiver (care and protection)
Civic role: The caring citizen
Values: Safety, Solidarity, Trust
Shadow: Carries too much, for too long.
Gift: Makes sure no one is left behind.
Message: Care is society’s quietest — but strongest — infrastructure.
After a few years: Society holds together — but those who carry the most risk becoming exhausted.
Reflective question: Do you often take extra responsibility when someone risks being left out?
Advice: Ask for relief in time — care becomes sustainable when it is shared.

The Trickster.text:
Jungian archetype: The Trickster (questioning and play)
Civic role: The questioning citizen
Values: Creativity, Transparency, Renewal
Shadow: Not taken seriously when it truly matters.
Gift: Exposes the absurdity of power without preaching.
Message: Laughter can open doors that anger closes.
After a few years: Society is creative and self-critical — sometimes longer than necessary.
Reflective question: Do you often use humor or irony to point out problems?
Advice: Let the joke be followed by a clear point so the insight remains.

The Enforcer.text:
Jungian archetype: The Ruler (order and control)
Civic role: The responsible citizen
Values: Order, Responsibility, Direction
Shadow: Control that suffocates what is alive.
Gift: Creates frameworks where others can act safely.
Message: Structure is not the opposite of freedom — it is its condition.
After a few years: Society is stable and well-organized — sometimes at the expense of spontaneity.
Reflective question: Do you feel a need to create clear boundaries when things get messy?
Advice: Always leave an opening — that’s where development can take shape.
